Russia is a major partner in the effort to build the space station.
Stansbury says NASA has contacted Russian officials about the debris from these satellite breakups in the past but hasn't really gotten anywhere.
They just haven't responded.
Jonathan McDowell at Harvard says most analysts think that the Russians are ordering these satellites to self-destruct, an old practice of trying to keep them out of enemy hands.
It does seem like the initial explosion happens as it's flying within the range of the Russian tracking stations, which leads one to imagine that it's them sending a radio signal going blow up now.
The Russians used to do this during the Cold War, he says, but recently, most satellites have gone quietly.
He says there's always been a mystery to the break-ups when they happen.
Like this one, they sometimes explode multiple times.
It's possible the later convulsions are due to leftover fuel igniting.
He can't see why you'd need to blow something up three times.
And I've been kind of thinking for 20 years, like what are these things up to, and I have not been able to come up with a good explanation.
Gene Stansbury at NASA says he hears the Russians are retiring this perplexing model of satellite and may not ever launch one again.

New York Times photographer Tyler Hicks has been documenting life and war in Afghanistan since the U.S.
invasion in 2001.
He recently got back from another trip.
He was embedded with a Marine unit in Helmand Province in the south, which has seen a strong resurgence of the Taliban.
He also spent time in Kabul, and his photo essay of life in the Afghan capital appeared in yesterday's Times.
Tyler, how would you compare Kabul that you saw on this most recent trip with the city that you first saw back in 2001?
Well, my introduction to Kabul in 2001, I was with Northern Alliance soldiers as they fought the Taliban entering the city.
So there was a lot of confusion and violence right as I arrived, but today it's a lot calmer in Kabul, although you have isolated events that can be even more dramatic than that day in 2001.

A number of the photos that you have in this photo essay document what you call a beggar society that has sprung up in Kabul, with refugees coming back from Pakistan, not finding work, and the consequences of that.
And I'm looking at a picture right now of a woman who's wearing a burka, and she's bent over.
She's sitting on the ground next to her son who's lying there.
He's apparently ill, and she's begging for help.
Yes.
These scenes surprise me, even having traveled all over Africa in some of the poorest countries in the world.
Each time I've been back to Afghanistan, it's really - you see a lot more people on the street, a lot more people who appear to be very sick, malnourished.

In this particular case, this is actually the first day I was working on this project, and this particular woman and son grabbed my interest because they were so isolated, and that's kind of what I was trying to convey in the photograph with the emptiness around the photo.

They were really alone, and this boy was so sick, in fact, that after I took these photographs, the driver that I was working with, who I've been working with regularly since 2001, kind of checked on the boy and looked at his eyes, and there's very little reaction to being touched in that way.
And it was very sad.
Was anyone giving this woman money?
One thing about Afghanistan, on a positive side, is that people are generous.
They do stop and give coins here and there to people.
It's not completely something where people just turn their back on it.

One of your other images, and these are all black-and-white images, very stark and striking, shows men in an opium den, and it's a reminder that - that Afghanistan is the largest opium producer in the world, and you say addiction there on the rise.
Yes, yes.
This is something else that I've seen a lot more of, not only this drug use, but really almost kind of a public display of this kind of use.
I mean, whether you be in a park where families gather, you can kind of smell hashish in the air.

Or in this case, I was actually just wandering around kind of the old city, looking for photographs of kind of the old, destroyed buildings left over from the Soviet occupation during the fighting there.
And I turned one corner, and I came across this very large group of men smoking, shooting heroin.
And it was a very big surprise to me to see this amount of men in the middle of the day, on a weekday, using drugs like this.
I was happy to see, Tyler, in the middle of all these photos of desperation and sadness, an image of four children on a kind of makeshift swing set.
They're all on a - each of them is on a seat, swinging around a central pole, and they look like they just don't have a care in the world.
Yes.
Yeah, and that's the thing that makes you feel better sometimes.
I mean, kids will always be kids, and they want to have fun and laugh and enjoy themselves just like anyone else.
Where was that picture taken?

That was just outside of also another kind of refugee area, where people - and these were very poor children as well, most of them living in kind of makeshift tents, but they were doing what they could to have a good time.
We've been talking with New York Times photographer Tyler Hicks, and you can find images from his photo essay on Afghanistan at our Web site, npr.org.
Tyler, thanks so much.
Thank you.

Thousands of volunteers are now pouring into the Katrina disaster zone from across the country.
Some are trained medics or heavy equipment operators; others just want to help.
These do-it-yourselfers are headed south with chain saws, bottled water and a ton of goodwill.
But aid officials are concerned some volunteers may become part of the problem.
NPR's Eric Niiler has more.
After a couple of days of watching disaster footage on CNN, Carlos Gavidia said he had enough.
He owns a successful financial services company in Virginia, and says he couldn't wait any longer.
I'm more of an action guy.
And so I called my partner and I said, `Let's do something.
Instead of just giving money to the Red Cross, let's hand-deliver something.'
Gavidia and his partner bought $100,000 worth of meals ready to eat from a South Carolina contractor.
They got Safeway and Costco to donate bottled water.
A buddy from Boston loaned his 18-wheeler, and they're trying to get another one for all the supplies.
The convoy leaves in a few days.
Destination?
Gulfport, Mississippi.
People tried to discourage me, tell me, `Oh, no, let the government handle it.
Let them do it.
But this is just too devastating, and I've just been compelled that I've got to done something today, now.
Gavidia's can-do attitude is being repeated across the country.
Do-it-yourself aid convoys are loading up in many cities, including New York, Chicago, Charlotte and Cleveland.
Many are being organized by local radio or TV stations, or on the Internet through community Web sites such as craigslist.
Online, it's easy to see all the people who want to help.
But Marietta Basil(ph) with the American Red Cross in Washington says all this help may be too much of a good thing.
Well, the major problem is that often there's no one on that end to receive them.
So it creates chaos and disappointment.
Basil says many volunteers who show up in a disaster zone don't know what they're doing.
This was especially true earlier this year after the tsunami struck Indonesia when hundreds of Westerners arrived days later with little food or water of their own.
Without training, a plan and a destination, Basil says they're more like disaster tourists.
They can really tax the resources and kind of be more of a hindrance than a help, actually.
